text: - Hello everybody at re:Invent.

Today we're coming to
you from sunny Singapore

and we're really excited
to have James and Sashi
both here with us from Goldman Sachs.

They're both executive
directors of technology

and they've been working
very closely with us

on building out a managed
file transfer service.
James?
- Yeah.
- Goldman Sachs is a really well-respected
financial services firm.
Can you tell me a little bit more
about your role at the bank
and what you've been doing on the project?

- Sure, so I look after
two tech teams there.
So first of all, I look after
the grid compute technology team.
So that's the grid compute
that's used for a lot of the risk
and pricing throughout the bank

using quite a lot of cloud
technology in there as well.
So, also I look after the MFT team.

So we have our own internal
MFT solution called SFX

and that's basically the
file transfers solution.
- Okay, thanks.
- And Sashi?
- Yeah, sure.
I'm Cloud Enablement Team lead.

The Cloud Enablement Team
is responsible to bring in

or enable public cloud
technologies within the firm

using industry best practices
in the agile fashion.
My other role is to work
with different business departments,

advise them on a cloud
migration, cloud design.

Like one of the team I'm
working with is SFX with James.
- Okay, great.
And Sashi, could you just tell us
a little bit more about
the importance of cloud at Goldman Sachs?
- Sure.

So, I think this question
had been answered
by our leadership in many public forums,
like re:Invent and Investor's Forum.
I'll summarize quickly for you, right?
So really two things.
One is accelerate the innovation, right?

And second is delightful
developer experience, right?

Like, you know, make your
developer more productive
using bleeding edge,
cutting edge technologies within the firm
and accelerate the innovation.

What we really want to do is
become a vertical bank, right?
Using cloud technologies,
do all the heavy lifting for our client,
provide differentiated service
and digital platform which basically meets

all the regulatory and
compliance requirements.
- Okay, thanks, thanks Sashi.

And James, could you just
tell me a little bit more

about the importance of
managed file transfer
for Goldman Sachs?
- Yeah, of course.
So, if you think about it,
data is really the lifeblood of a bank.
We're nothing, we can't operate
without data being interchanged
between us and our regulators,
us and our vendors and our clients.

So, we need to do that
reliably every single day.

So, it's absolutely
critical for our operation.
- All right, got it.
All right thanks, thanks James.
And when I think of managed file transfer

and I think of the
financial services industry,
obviously you guys are heavily regulated.
You're working with trading partners,
you've got a number of other partners

that you have to inter-operate
with and exchange data with.
Can you James, give us an idea of the size

and the scale of what
you have to deal with
on a daily basis?
- Sure.

So, if you look at how many
people in organizations
that we have to interact with,
this is means that we literally have

to transfer millions of
files every single day.
So we're delivering files to people,
we're collecting files from people,
we're making files available to people.

And this all has to be done,
like say, very reliably

and we have to manage this
very sort of bursty nature

of this delivery because
people need to access files
at the right time,

they need files delivered
at the right time.
- Yeah.

So the timeliness is
incredibly important I'm sure.
And to you James, again Goldman Sachs is,
as I mentioned before, it's regulated.
You guys have a lot of constraints on you
and also you've got a technology plan
that's been in place for a long time
and I'm sure you've got constraints

on how you integrate,
et cetera, et cetera.
Could you just sort of explain maybe

some of the complexities
and some of the things
that you've had to deal with

to actually implement a new
managed file transfer service?
- Sure, yeah.

So, if you think about
FTP, SFTP as a protocol,
they're pretty old protocols, right?
So, why is this even a hard problem?
It's a hard problem because

there are so many
different implementations
of these protocols.

There are so many different
remote system behaviors
that we have to interact with
and we don't necessarily have any control
over those implementations.

So, the problem is in
the number of edge cases
that we have to work around,

we have to provide a
solution for our clients

to interact with these
highly heterogeneous systems.
- All right, got it.
And Sashi, just coming to you,
are there any other features
or key requirements you need to meet?
- I would pick up from where James left.

So, James highlighted the
scalability, availability,
resiliency requirement, right?

To have a highly available
file transfer solution, right?
The other bit which I would mention is,

think about like you're
gonna be sending files

to your clients or
regulators or receiving file
and sending within the firm, right?

How do you ensure that the
file is scanned, right?

File is safe to be
distributed around, right?

So, definitely that I would
count as a critical feature.

- And James, could you
sort of maybe explain

to the audience at re:Invent
some of the complexities
and challenges that you've had

in implementing a managed
file transfer service?

- So, going back to the
heterogeneous nature
of what we're dealing with,
there is so much complexity in that

and that combined with
the number of clients
that we have to deal with,
the number of internal business units
that we have to deal with,
these all compounds to the complexity,
but all of this has to meet SLAs, right?
People want files delivered on time.

They send us a file that
needs to be delivered
to a regulator within x amount of minutes,
that needs to go there on time

and they need to be confident
that that can happen.
- Right.
So what sounds like

a very simple service--
- Yes.
- is actually quite complex,

especially when you're dealing
with this kind of scale
that Goldman Sachs deals with.

- Yes, underneath this
quite simple concept,

there's an ocean of edge
cases and spikes in demand,

that is bursty nature
that I was talking about,

that really, really does
add to the complexity

of the solution.
- Right.
And Sashi, just coming to you,
could you sort of explain

why Goldman Sachs didn't
choose to carry on
building their own service?
Why did they choose to partner with us,

AWS on building out a managed
file transfer service?
- Yeah.
Think about it, right?
What we are trying to achieve,

like with all the scale and
complexity aside, right?

We are trying to send a
file and receive a file.
And it's an old protocol, right?

Like why it is just
not a commodity, right?
Why we can't just...
It's there and then we can deliver file
and receive file, right?

Why do we need to maintain
such a large piece

of infrastructure code and deal
with all these complexities?

And we got a question
also from our leadership,
why it is not a Black Box, right?

And that's when we started
thinking about what to do

and precisely two years
ago I was at re:Invent

and I was discussing with
your AWS Transfer Service

about like, this is
something we are thinking
and I think AWS Transfer Service
recognized the industry-wide applicability

and they approached us
that we can collaborate
and we shared our IP,

like, you know what we
have learned over the years

and we're looking forward
to what comes out of this.
- Yeah.

- And it's been a great
partnership working with you guys,
we've had the AWS Transfer Family team,

we've had ProServ, we've
had Amazon Managed Services

all coming together and
working very closely

with Goldman Sachs to
meet your requirements
and it's been fun.
And James, I just wanna come on
to something which is more to do
with the heart of the solution
and really talk about the heart,
you've got SFTP and you've got S3.

And we mentioned a little
bit earlier about workflows.

Can you, kind of zoom in
and sort of talk about

the features and what
you see is the things

that really act as a bit
of a game changer for you.
- So, for me the important part here

is the ability to have these
workflows, like you mentioned.
So, having workflows

as part of this sort of
file transfer workflow,
it really gives the users a lot of power
in terms of the routing
and what happens to their file in transit
and that kind of really makes this
a platform for innovation,
if you look at it that way.
- Yeah.
- He used the right word,
like platform of innovation, right?
And I'll expand on that how it is,
platform for innovation, right?
Think about it, right?
You receive the file
and you still need,

like people need to
process that file, right?

And you have all the
sorts of data pipeline,
data analytics, building rolling out
your best book solution.
Now, having that in the cloud
and delivering that to an AWS S3 bucket,
really opens the door for us, right?
Like you can build all your data pipeline,

data analytics, AI,
ML, what sort what not.
And it also further our cloud strategy.
- Yeah, thanks.
Now, I really wanna thank you both today

for your time and sharing
your story with everybody
on stage at re:Invent
and just to sort of summarize,
Goldman Sachs have been very pivotal

in helping and inputting
into the development
for the AWS Transfer Family.

And I'm sure the guys on
stage will talk to you more
about some of the future capabilities
that are now being released.

And I just wanna thank
James and Sashi again,
really fantastic.
And back to you on stage at re:Invent,
Thank you very much.
